romainfrancois commented on a change in pull request #11534:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11534#discussion_r735734467



##########
File path: r/tests/testthat/test-dplyr-funcs-string.R
##########
@@ -120,10 +120,10 @@ test_that("paste, paste0, and str_c", {
 
   # sep is literal NA
   # errors in paste() (consistent with base::paste())
-  expect_error(
-    nse_funcs$paste(x, y, sep = NA_character_),
-    "Invalid separator"
-  )
+  expect_snapshot({
+    (expect_error(nse_funcs$paste(x, y, sep = NA_character_)))

Review comment:
       I tend to have it like this: 
   
   ```r
     (expect_error(
       nse_funcs$paste(x, y, sep = NA_character_)
     ))
   ```
   
   so that I can more easily select the `nse_funcs$paste(x, y, sep = NA_character_)` to e.g. copy and paste when developing the tests, but that makes more lines ... 
   
   `rlang` has this defined in its helpers: 
   
   ```r
   err <- function(...) (expect_error(...))
   ```




--

   How exactly is this better? To my eyes, there are a bunch of extra parentheses everywhere, and the expected behavior (error message) has been moved so that it's no longer next to the test code, which makes it harder to read the tests to see what's happening.

romainfrancois commented on pull request #11534:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11534#issuecomment-951933363


   You would then locally use `testthat::snapshot_preview()` to see what has changed, and/or the diff view in the pull request when you propose changes to error messages, etc ...
   
   It does take some getting used to, but at least in my experience of embracing this in `dplyr`, it really helped curate the error messages. 


--

jonkeane commented on pull request #11534:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11534#issuecomment-961271239


   I share some of Neals concerns about readability, but overall I think this pattern will help us more than it will hurt us going forward. The [improvement suggested of adding a helper](https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11534#discussion_r735734467) that wraps some of the extra parens, etc. will address some of that (could we add that in on this PR and see how it looks?)
   
   We should also see what others think about this pattern and if we want to start using it more broadly (and slowly move our current tests over, but I think we can do that as we interact with them and don't need to dedicate time to moving everything over all at once).
   
   We could ➕ / ➖  on this comment to indicate which way we want to go


--

dragosmg commented on pull request #11534:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11534#issuecomment-961860067


   This is how the same chunk of code would look like with a helper function:
   ```
     expect_snapshot({
       err(
         nse_funcs$str_to_lower("Apache Arrow", locale = "sp")
       )
     })
     ```
     
   without the helper function:
   ```  
     expect_snapshot({
        (expect_error(
          nse_funcs$str_to_lower("Apache Arrow", locale = "sp")
        ))
      })
   ```
   where `err` is `err <- function(...) (expect_error(...))`. imho it makes the code a bit easier on the eyes. let me know what you think. 
   
   


--

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

comments.body: Do you think we should use {{expect_snapshot()}} for all instances of {{expect_error()}} or just some?

I think we should definitely use {{expect_snapshot()}} for the tests where we are providing the error message to compare to / check against. Not sure it's relevant to swap for every instance of {{expect_error()}} at this stage. We could extend if we want to keep an eye on the messages accompanying the errors.
I guess there also may be further complications for the tests for functions which raise both the original C++ error and an extra R error message too.

For the functions that surface C++ errors, which might be a bit more weird to handle, we have several options:
* not use {{expect_snapshot()}} for them
* make use of the {{transform}} argument that allows us to scrub text from the output
* wait for cpp11 to support classed errors (https://github.com/r-lib/cpp11/issues/250)

Using {{expect_error()}} with the {{regexp}} argument for testing messages is a bit clunky when the error (or condition) message is more complex (such as enabled by switching condition handling to {{rlang}}). This is one of the use cases in which the power of {{expect_snapshot()}} shines through.
